article.headline: Teslaâs stock story is one of newbs and rubes â but not quite the way you think it is
article.body: Thereâs an old saying in poker: donât just play the cards, play the players. Itâs the same thing in markets. You canât just focus on the cards youâre dealt, i.e., the fundamentals of this stock or that stock. You also have to focus on the other players who are playing these same cards, and that means understanding the behavior of a crowd of buyers and sellers in the stock market. Just like in poker, sometimes the cards/fundamentals donât matter at all. Sometimes poker players will think they have an edge in understanding the other players sitting around the table, and before you know it, thereâs a huge pot in the middle of the table regardless of what cards have been dealt. Thatâs exactly what has happened with Tesla TSLA, +1.89% stock over the past few months. Thereâs a huge pot of money in the middle of the table in the form of an enormous market cap for Tesla as the stock keeps getting bid up, and none of it has anything to do with the fundamentals of the company. And, despite what I know youâve heard, almost none of it has anything to do with people buying the stock because itâs âcheaperâ since the stock split. Oh sure, weâve all heard stories of the idiot friend of a friend who either thinks theyâre getting four brand new shares of Tesla with the 5-for-one split or believes itâs more âaffordableâ now that itâs been split. But the truth is that fractional share purchases have been a standard feature of every retail Davey Day Traderâs online stock trading platform for months and months. If you wanted to buy $100 worth of Tesla stock, you didnât need a stock split to make that happen (and the stock split didnât lower the price per share to that level anyway). These stories about the idiot friend of a friend are just that â stories. They arenât entirely apocryphal, maybe, but nowhere near even a rounding error in the average daily trading volume (more than 70 million shares a day) of Tesla stock. The feeding frenzy on Tesla has nothing to do with that handful of rubes buying the stock because itâs more âaffordableâ after the split. It has something to do with traders buying the stock because they believe the story that there will be rubes buying the stock because itâs more âaffordableâ after the split. And it has everything to do with traders buying the stock because they believe that other traders believe the story that there will be rubes buying the stock because itâs more âaffordableâ after the split. This is the Common Knowledge Game in action. It is the power of the crowd watching the crowd. It is the power of not what you think is true, and not what you think the crowd thinks is true, but of what the crowd thinks the crowd thinks is true. Today, the crowd thinks the crowd thinks that there are newbs and rubes buying the stock because itâs cheaper post-split. And that is whatâs driving the feeding frenzy in Tesla shares. Apple AAPL, +1.74% Â , too. Itâs an old idea in investing, dating back at least to John Maynard Keynes in the 1930s, who called it the Newspaper Beauty Contest to use as market analogy the social media of his day. Maybe we should call it the Robinhood Effect. Read: Popular trading platforms TD Ameritrade, Robinhood, and others faced outages early Monday as Tesla and Apple stocks split But in both the 1930s and the 2020s, the idea is the same: in markets like these, the fundamentals donât matter. You can play any hand youâre dealt! What matters is the story around a company or a stock, and what matters even more is whether itâs a story that everyone believes that everyone else believes. How does the game end? When you stop reading stories about the idiot friend of a friend buying âcheapâ Tesla shares for the first time. Not because there were ever enough of these newbs and rubes to actually make a difference in Tesla price action, but because the story that these newbs and rubes are out there will be broken. Youâve seen exactly that happen in the past few days. Now that the stock split is over and there are no new online articles shouting âidiots who donât understand stock splits will be buying Tesla hand over fist!â, the Common Knowledge Game breaks the other way. Read: Teslaâs stock sinks again on Wednesday to kick off a correction after disclosure of another large seller But you know who understands this game really well? Elon Musk. Tim Cook, too. Thatâs why Tesla is selling up to $5 billion worth of fresh stock while the price is so high. Think of it as the house taking their rake from the overinflated pot of money now sitting in the middle of the poker table. So donât worry about Elon and Tim. Theyâll find another story to drive another round of the Common Knowledge Game. They always do. Ben Hunt is co-founder and chief investment officer at Second Foundation Partners and also writes on his Epsilon Theory website. Follow him on Twitter @EpsilonTheory.
